SourcedStatement: "It's obvious that running against Harris is more challenging for Trump given the shift in these numbers, but it's certainly not insurmountable," Matt Wolking, a Republican campaign strategist who worked on Trump's 2020 campaign, said in response to the Reuters/Ipsos poll results.
Name: Matt Wolking
Title: Republican campaign strategist
Justification: Matt Wolking's expertise as a Republican campaign strategist and his prior work on Trump's 2020 campaign provide insight into the challenges Trump faces in the current race.

SourcedStatement: He said Trump needs to stay as focused as possible in his campaign "so he's not scaring" away voters who were leaning his way because they didn't like Biden.
Name: Matt Wolking
Title: Republican campaign strategist
Justification: Matt Wolking's analysis offers strategic advice for Trump's campaign, reflecting his expertise and experience.

SourcedStatement: "We see it in this poll that people are more motivated about the future than the past," said Aimee Allison, founder of She the People, a liberal group that aims to grow the numbers of women of color in elected office.
Name: Aimee Allison
Title: Founder of She the People
Justification: Aimee Allison's role as founder of She the People and her focus on women of color in politics provide context to her interpretation of the poll results.

SourcedStatement: "They see Kamala Harris as the future, and Republicans see this election as just about Trump. Voters are more likely to be engaged when given the option of 'more than' beating Trump."
Name: Aimee Allison
Title: Founder of She the People
Justification: Aimee Allison's perspective highlights the contrasting motivations of voters, informed by her work in political advocacy.

SourcedStatement: Democrat Kamala Harris leads Republican Donald Trump 45% to 41% in a Reuters/Ipsos poll published on Thursday that showed the vice president sparking new enthusiasm among voters and shaking up the race ahead of the Nov. 5 election.
Name: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Justification: The Reuters/Ipsos poll provides statistical data on voter preferences and trends, which is central to the article's analysis of the election.

SourcedStatement: The 4 percentage point advantage among registered voters was wider than a 1 point lead Harris held over the former president in a late July Reuters/Ipsos poll.
Name: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Justification: The Reuters/Ipsos poll offers a comparison of voter trends over time, illustrating Harris's growing lead.

SourcedStatement: A separate Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll published later on Thursday showed that Harris was either leading or tied with Trump in each of those states.
Name: Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll
Justification: The Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll provides additional data on state-level voter preferences, complementing the national trends discussed.

SourcedStatement: That poll showed Harris led Trump by 2 percentage points among registered voters across the seven states and was ahead by 1 point — a statistical tie — among likely voters.
Name: Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll
Justification: The Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll offers detailed insights into voter preferences in key battleground states.

SourcedStatement: The poll was conducted nationally and gathered responses from 4,253 U.S. adults, including 3,562 registered voters.
Name: Reuters/Ipsos poll
Justification: The Reuters/Ipsos poll's methodology and sample size provide credibility and context to the findings presented in the article.

SourcedStatement: Some 73% of Democratic registered voters in the Reuters/Ipsos poll said they were more excited about voting in November after Harris entered the race.
Name: Democratic registered voters
Justification: Democratic registered voters are a key demographic in the election and their enthusiasm is a significant indicator of voter engagement.

SourcedStatement: And while a March Reuters/Ipsos poll found that 61% respondents who intended to vote for Biden were doing so mainly to stop Trump, 52% of Harris voters in the August poll were voting to support her as a candidate rather than primarily to oppose Trump.
Name: Harris voters
Justification: Harris voters represent a shift in voter motivation, which is a critical factor in understanding the dynamics of the election.

SourcedStatement: But Trump voters also voiced enthusiasm about their candidate, with 64% saying their choice was more motivated by backing Trump than opposing Harris.
Name: Trump voters
Justification: Trump voters' enthusiasm highlights the strength of his base and their motivations, which are central to his campaign strategy.
